articles.headline: Obama Camp Sees Fine Line in Hitting Back
articles.snippet: The resignation of an adviser to Barack Obama sparked new debates about how far he should go in responding to attacks.
articles.abstract: The resignation of an adviser to Barack Obama sparked new debates about how far he should go in responding to attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: CASPER, Wyo.  Since opening his presidential bid 14 months ago, Senator Barack Obama of Illinois has answered many questions about his candidacy.

articles.headline: To Revive Hunting, States Turn to the Classroom
articles.snippet: West Virginia, which will allow hunting classes in schools, is one of many states trying to bolster a sport in decline.
articles.abstract: West Virginia, which will allow hunting classes in schools, is one of many states trying to bolster a sport in decline.
articles.lead_paragraph: MORGANTOWN, W.Va.  When David Helms was in seventh grade, he would take his .22-caliber rifle to school, put a box of ammunition in his locker and, like virtually all the other boys, lean his rifle against a wall in the principal’s office so he could start hunting squirrels and groundhogs as soon as classes let out.

articles.headline: Big Names in Retail Fashion Are Trading Teams
articles.snippet: Several major clothing designers plan to shift to different stores, creating transitions that could confuse consumers.
articles.abstract: Several major clothing designers plan to shift to different stores, creating transitions that could confuse consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s free-agency season in American fashion.
articles.byline: By Eric Wilson and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: Sharp Drop in Jobs Adds to Grim Economic Picture
articles.snippet: The worst fears of investors and officials were confirmed as paralysis on Wall Street collided with new evidence of a likely recession.
articles.abstract: The worst fears of investors and officials were confirmed as paralysis on Wall Street collided with new evidence of a likely recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The worst fears of consumers, investors and Washington officials were confirmed on Friday, as deepening paralysis on Wall Street collided with stark new evidence of falling employment and a likely recession.

articles.headline: Chiefs’ Pay Under Fire at Capitol
articles.snippet: Three prominent executives defended the multimillion-dollar pay they received even as their firms struggled through the spreading credit crisis.
articles.abstract: Three prominent executives defended the multimillion-dollar pay they received even as their firms struggled through the spreading credit crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In pointed exchanges with Congressional lawmakers Friday, three prominent financial executives defended the multimillion-dollar pay packages they received even as their companies were brought to their knees by the spreading credit crisis.

articles.headline: Tight Credit, Tough Times for Buyout Lords
articles.snippet: The Ides of March has arrived early for the buyout lords of Wall Street, as the intensifying credit crisis humbles some of the industry’s once-celebrated deal makers.
articles.abstract: The Ides of March has arrived early for the buyout lords of Wall Street, as the intensifying credit crisis humbles some of the industry’s once-celebrated deal makers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just over a year ago, William E. Conway Jr., a founding partner of the Carlyle Group, celebrated the riches that easy credit were bringing to the kings of Wall Street.

articles.headline: Got a Mint, Comrade? Chinese Ban Liquid Lunch
articles.snippet: A Communist Party campaign in Xinyang, China, seeks to catch civil servants partaking of alcohol-soaked meals.
articles.abstract: A Communist Party campaign in Xinyang, China, seeks to catch civil servants partaking of alcohol-soaked meals.
articles.lead_paragraph: XINYANG, China  Li Bin, a barrel-chested retiree on special assignment for this city’s Communist Party boss, strode down an empty hallway of the Xinyang Middle Court in search of bureaucrats. He rattled locked doorknobs and barged into offices without knocking. A court officer retreated in red-faced terror.

articles.headline: Seeing an End to the Good Times (Such as They Were)
articles.snippet: If history is a reliable guide, a dismal jobs report suggests that the recession of 2008 is now unavoidable.
articles.abstract: If history is a reliable guide, a dismal jobs report suggests that the recession of 2008 is now unavoidable.
articles.lead_paragraph: If history is a reliable guide, the recession of 2008 is now unavoidable.

articles.headline: Concern in Europe on Cellphone Ads for Children
articles.snippet: Driven in part by a lack of knowledge over the long-term health effects of mobile phone use, parent groups in Europe have called for a ban on marketing to children.
articles.abstract: Driven in part by a lack of knowledge over the long-term health effects of mobile phone use, parent groups in Europe have called for a ban on marketing to children.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  The MO1 beginner mobile phone is not as cuddly as a teddy bear, but manufacturers of the curvy crimson-and-blue handset for 6-year-olds promise a similarly warm and fuzzy relationship. They boast about socialization, emotional health and the comforts of “peace of mind.”

articles.headline: A Case of Abuse, Heightened
articles.snippet: A condemning video is delayed, then leaked to the media, and an animal rights activist makes the most of the spotlight.
articles.abstract: A condemning video is delayed, then leaked to the media, and an animal rights activist makes the most of the spotlight.
articles.lead_paragraph: “We are playing Russian roulette with the American food supply,” thundered Wayne Pacelle.

articles.headline: A Global Need for Grain That Farms Can’t Fill
articles.snippet: When much of the country is contemplating recession, farmers are flourishing because of runaway demand.
articles.abstract: When much of the country is contemplating recession, farmers are flourishing because of runaway demand.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAWTON, N.D.  Whatever Dennis Miller decides to plant this year on his 2,760-acre farm, the world needs. Wheat prices have doubled in the last six months. Corn is on a tear. Barley, sunflower seeds, canola and soybeans are all up sharply.

articles.headline: Book Lovers Ask, What’s Seattle’s Secret?
articles.snippet: Though the big publishing houses are still in New York, the Seattle area is home to Amazon, Starbucks and Costco, companies that increasingly influence what America reads.
articles.abstract: Though the big publishing houses are still in New York, the Seattle area is home to Amazon, Starbucks and Costco, companies that increasingly influence what America reads.
articles.lead_paragraph: Seattle

articles.headline: Downturn Tests the Fed’s Ability to Avert a Crisis
articles.snippet: Lenders and businesses are becoming more cautious about whom they lend to and hire, slowing the economy further.
articles.abstract: Lenders and businesses are becoming more cautious about whom they lend to and hire, slowing the economy further.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the last seven months, policy makers have cut interest rates, injected money into the banking system and approved a fiscal stimulus package in an effort to keep the economy from slipping into a recession. Often, the moves seemed to work at first, only to be overtaken by more bad news.

articles.headline: Text Generation Gap: U R 2 Old (JK)
articles.snippet: Children increasingly rely on personal technological devices to create social circles apart from their families, changing the way they communicate with their parents.
articles.abstract: Children increasingly rely on personal technological devices to create social circles apart from their families, changing the way they communicate with their parents.
articles.lead_paragraph: AS president of the Walt Disney Company’s children’s book and magazine publishing unit, Russell Hampton knows a thing or two about teenagers. Or he thought as much until he was driving his 14-year-old daughter, Katie, and two friends to a play last year in Los Angeles.

articles.headline: As Good as Cash, Until It’s Not
articles.snippet: Investors across the nation are finding themselves in Wall Street’s version of the Hotel California: they have checked into an investment they can never leave.
articles.abstract: Investors across the nation are finding themselves in Wall Street’s version of the Hotel California: they have checked into an investment they can never leave.
articles.lead_paragraph: INVESTORS across the nation are finding themselves in Wall Street’s version of the Hotel California: they have checked into an investment they can never leave.

articles.headline: Obama in Senate: Star Power, Minor Role
articles.snippet: In Barack Obama’s time in the Senate, there are two competing elements: his celebrity and the realities of the job he was elected to do.
articles.abstract: In Barack Obama’s time in the Senate, there are two competing elements: his celebrity and the realities of the job he was elected to do.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Barack Obama stood before Washington’s elite at the spring dinner of the storied Gridiron Club. In self-parody, he ticked off his accomplishments, little more than a year after arriving in town.
articles.byline: By Kate Zernike and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Pakistan Rivals Join to Fight Musharraf
articles.snippet: The leaders of the two major political parties agreed that they would reinstate the judges the Pakistani president fired, which may create a challenge to his presidency.
articles.abstract: The leaders of the two major political parties agreed that they would reinstate the judges the Pakistani president fired, which may create a challenge to his presidency.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The leaders of the two major political parties here, in an unexpectedly strong show of unity against President Pervez Musharraf, agreed Sunday that they would reinstate the judges fired by the president and would seek to strip him of crucial powers.

articles.headline: TV Puts an Odd Lens on Politics
articles.snippet: Since political coverage has migrated to the cable networks, the tenor and texture of campaign reporting are changing as well.
articles.abstract: Since political coverage has migrated to the cable networks, the tenor and texture of campaign reporting are changing as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last Tuesday, millions of viewers were riveted by the wrestling match in Ohio and gunfight in Texas between Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama, not to mention by the unlikely coronation of the conservative bugbear John McCain as the Republican nominee.

articles.headline: Cable Firms Join Forces to Attract Focused Ads
articles.snippet: The nation’s six largest cable companies are planning a jointly owned company that would allow national advertisers to buy customized ads across their systems.
articles.abstract: The nation’s six largest cable companies are planning a jointly owned company that would allow national advertisers to buy customized ads across their systems.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an effort to slow Google’s siphoning of advertising dollars away from television, the nation’s six largest cable companies are making plans for a jointly owned company that would allow national advertisers to buy customized ads and interactive ads across the companies’ systems.

articles.headline: New Challenge to Times Board: Dissidents With Large Stake
articles.snippet: Management at The New York Times Company is facing another challenge from dissident investors complaining of poor decision-making.
articles.abstract: Management at The New York Times Company is facing another challenge from dissident investors complaining of poor decision-making.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last year, The New York Times Company fended off a major investor who complained of poor decision-making and was bent on shaking up the company. This year, management is facing another challenge from dissident investors with similar criticisms.

articles.headline: Sniping by Aides Hurt Clinton’s Image as Manager
articles.snippet: Internal second-guessing undermined Hillary Rodham Clinton’s image as a steady-at-the-wheel chief surrounded by a phalanx of loyal and efficient aides.
articles.abstract: Internal second-guessing undermined Hillary Rodham Clinton’s image as a steady-at-the-wheel chief surrounded by a phalanx of loyal and efficient aides.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by Adam Nagourney, Patrick Healy and Kate Zernike.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney, Patrick Healy and Kate Zernike

articles.headline: Serving Up Television Without the TV Set
articles.snippet: Watching television online is now a common activity for millions, with one in four Internet users watching a full-length show online in the last three months.
articles.abstract: Watching television online is now a common activity for millions, with one in four Internet users watching a full-length show online in the last three months.
articles.lead_paragraph: The “stupid computer” is a repeated target of the dimwitted office manager Michael Scott on “The Office.” But the show itself may be motivating viewers to put down their remote controls and pick up their laptops.

articles.headline: Going to the Company Elders for Help
articles.snippet: Hewlett-Packard is trying to galvanize thousands of its retirees into an auxiliary army of senior marketers, good-will ambassadors and volunteer sales people.
articles.abstract: Hewlett-Packard is trying to galvanize thousands of its retirees into an auxiliary army of senior marketers, good-will ambassadors and volunteer sales people.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif.  On a recent Saturday afternoon, John Toppel, a retired Hewlett-Packard sales manager, did not spend his leisure time golfing or mowing the lawn. He spent it at a local electronics store extolling the virtues of H.P. laptop computers to customers.

articles.headline: In Tanker Bid, It Was Boeing vs. Bold Ideas
articles.snippet: Boeing must decide by Wednesday whether to file an appeal on the Pentagon’s contract with Airbus.
articles.abstract: Boeing must decide by Wednesday whether to file an appeal on the Pentagon’s contract with Airbus.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Just hours before the Air Force announced the winner of a $35 billion contract to build aerial refueling aircraft on Feb. 29, an Airbus plane lumbered off the runway in Getafe, Spain, and climbed to 27,000 feet to rendezvous with a Portuguese F-16 fighter.
articles.byline: By DAVID HERSZENHORN and JEFF BAILEY

articles.headline: To Aim Ads, Web Is Keeping Closer Eye on You
articles.snippet: A new analysis of online consumer data shows that large Web companies are learning more about people than ever from what they search for and do on the Internet.
articles.abstract: A new analysis of online consumer data shows that large Web companies are learning more about people than ever from what they search for and do on the Internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: A famous New Yorker cartoon from 1993 showed two dogs at a computer, with one saying to the other, “On the Internet, nobody knows you’re a dog.”

articles.headline: McCain Uses Breathing Room to Focus on Coffers
articles.snippet: John McCain has time he can use to unite his party and transform his operation into a general election machine, though the lull could also have drawbacks.
articles.abstract: John McCain has time he can use to unite his party and transform his operation into a general election machine, though the lull could also have drawbacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sewing up the Republican presidential nomination while the Democratic candidates continue to battle each other has given Senator John McCain a valuable commodity: time he can use to unite a fractured Republican Party, ramp up his lackluster fund-raising and transform his shoestring primary operation into a general election machine.
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper and Michael Luo
